newsitem.title: USA: New York City mayor pushes for bigger tax cuts.
newsitem.headline: New York City mayor pushes for bigger tax cuts.

text.p: New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, whose preliminary fiscal 1998 budget includes ending the city's four-percent sales tax on clothing, called for even bigger reductions for residents and businesses in later years.

Ending the city's sales tax on clothing that costs less than $500 by December 31 would cost New York City about $157 million in revenues in fiscal 1998, and around $279 million in 1999, the first full year of the tax break that must be approved by Albany.

The state also assesses a four percent tax on clothing, and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is partly funded with a 0.25 percent levy, and Giuliani has recommended that both these taxes be abolished, saying the indirect benefits over time could help make up for the drop in tax collections.
Raising the tax credit for unincorporated businesses would save businesses a total of $53 million in fiscal 1998 and $57 million the next year, the mayor estimated.
The Administration also would give companies $30 million of tax relief in fiscal 1998 by adjusting commercial rent taxes, a sum that rises to $117 million in fiscal 1998.

The total amount of tax revenue that the city stands to lose under the mayor's new plan, which the City Council still must approve, would rise from $250 million in fiscal 1998 to $463 million in 1999 and $518 million in 2000.
